From: Colin Green <colin.green1@...>

Re. perceptual similarity/hasing, here's an interestign recent development:

   The differential geometry of perceptual similarity, Antonio M
Rodriguez, Richard Granger
   https://arxiv.org/abs/1708.00138

Also see:

    http://www.phash.org/

However I reviewed all the standard appoaches in about 2011 and I
recall not being too impressed. Most (or all?) of them started by
breaking an image into square blocks (as per JPEG encoding), which
immediately causes problems if you translate or rotate the image, or
crop it slightly differently, etc.

The fundamental issue I think is that to do it really well you need
actual learned general feature detectors, and AFAIK even the best DL
learned feature detectors still have 'issues', as per e.g. single
pixel 'attacks'.  Any approach that tries to take a shortcut by not
doing some form of image feature learning is going to have some edge
cases where it utterly fails, i.e. where a human would say "that's
obviously the same/different", but the hash says otherwise.

Colin
